author: mysticryuujin
content:
I asked this over in ligthhouse but maybe here's better:

What's the thoughts around Onyx and Altona both being multi-client testnets?

If we're getting closer to mainnet, wouldn't it be beneficial for us to unify into one to get maximum participation? Just wondering other's thoughts around coordination.

author: djrtwo
content:
The prysmatic team has found value in maintaining largely single client testnets over the past year to demo their software and to find and work through bugs in a scaled up environment but without added complexity of multi-client.

There will likely be some multi-client on Onyx but I expect the distribution to largely be Prysm. This heavy skew to one client will likely mask many multi-client issues like consensus errors, fork choice discrepancies, etc (while still likely being valuable for prysm testing)

I know Prysmatic has a large following and will likely have a large Onyx  network, but I hope that over the next month or so that community participation begins to favor the native multi-client nets (if we assume that hobbyists/users just want to run one testnet at a time). I won't predict the exact fate and/or numbers of these coming nets, but as a native and large-scale multi-client testnet becomes available, I will certainly encourage more of the community to run a diverse set of nodes there

author: raulj
content: +1 on the value of multiclient. For us at Prysmatic, having a testnet such as Onyx is mostly useful for user experience improvements, documentation, finding runtime bugs, etc. Multiclient testnets such as Altona are useful for finding critical consensus errors and other client-conformity related problems.

author: raulj
content: We do aim, however, to have a significant portion of validators on Onyx from other client implementations. We are already running some teku nodes for it in preparation for genesis

author: mysticryuujin
content: I guess my concern is for the people who rely on defaults to decide which network they join. I think the default should probably be multi-client. I wouldn't expect lighthouse or teku or another client to default to Onyx over Altona for instance, and that likely reduces multi-client participation by having Prysm default to their own? Then again, maybe they will, not sure.

author: protolambda
content: Maybe that can be avoided by not having a default at all, and providing easy access to the testnets with cli flags like `--testnet=onyx` `--testnet=altona` etc.

author: 1n1a5
content: Talking about CLI flags, I think it will be nice to have a standard for the command line interface, so that all clients recognize common options and behavior is identical.

author: 1n1a5
content: Just like GCC and Clang compiler flags.

author: protolambda
content: <@!701536321381990481> There are a lot of things we would like to standardize in this multi-client environment, but for some things we have to prioritize, and I would focus on API standardization primarily. Also, the CLI flags are not generic due to different client designs, thus hard to standardize.
